questions.text: An 68 year old patient came complaints of diplopia and severe headache and mild ocular heaviness of sudden onset. He has a history of a recent stroke also and there is atherosclerosis, diabetes and hypertension since many years. On ocular examination vision was 6/12 with an early cataract. Retina was normal. Pupil showed both absent direct and indirect light reflex on Right side. What CN is involved
questions.solution: Third nerve gives innervation to sphincter pupillae muscle, so if it is paralysed the pupil will remain dilated and will not constrict to light and accomodation. Also there will be no consensual light reflex in the affected side. This pupil is also known as efferent pupil. A history of diabetes and hypertension also suggest the same. Such a pupil (mid dilated nonreacting ) can be seen in aneuryrsm of ICA with cavernous sinus or any other surgical cause of 3rd nerve palsy

questions.text: Which membrane separates Scala Vestibuli and Scala Media?
questions.solution:
• Reissner's membrane separates Scala Vestibuli and Scalamedia
  • Basilar membrane separates Scala Media and Scala Tympani
  • Tectorial membrane covers Organ of corti
  • Secondary TM= round window membrane
  • Pars flaccida= sharpnell's membrane Travellingwave theory of hearing has been given by Von Bekesy which states that -

A sound wave depending on its frequency reaches maximum amplitude on a particular place in the basilar membrane and stimulates that segment. Therefore higher frequencies are sensed in basal turn and low frequencies are sensed in apex of cochlea.

choices.text: Branch of 3rd nerve is misdirected to pterygoid muscle
Ptosis increase with movement of pterygoid
Large levator resection is done for treatment

questions.text: False about Margus Gunn jaw winking phenomenon
questions.solution:
• Marcus Gunn phenomenon: This condition is characterized as a synkinesis when two or more muscles that are independently innervated have either simultaneous or coordinated movements. 5 % of all ptosis.
  • The stimulation of the trigeminal nerve by contraction of the pterygoid muscles of jaw results in the excitation of the branch of the oculomotor nerve that innervates the levator palpebrae superioris ipsilaterally (on the same side of the face), so the patient will have rhythmic upward jerking of their upper eyelid.
  • In severe cases, surgery with a bilateral levator excision and frontalis brow suspension may be used.

MARCUS GUNN PHENOMENON

questions.text: A 45 year old diabetic, hypertensive present with unilateral transient obscuration for 2-3 days followed by sudden diminution of vision. Which of the following tests would you order?
questions.solution: This case suggest a retinal vascular occlusion in young individual. Serum homocysteine levels have been found to an independent risk factor for them as well as ischemic heart disease, deep vein thrombosis and pulmonary embolism, stroke, and abdominal aortic aneurysm.

questions.text: In a patient of Quinsy, Trismus develops due to spasm of which muscle
questions.solution:
quinsy=peritonsillar abscess.

Tonsil is pushed medillay and uvula is deviated to other side. This is classical feature of quinsy. There is NO outer neck swelling in Quinsy. Patient has Trismus (due to spasm of medial pterygoid muscle), odynophagia, hot potato voice.

questions.text: Confrontation test is done for
questions.solution: a. A visual field testis an eye examination that can detect dysfunction in central and peripheral vision which may be caused by various medical conditions such as glaucoma, stroke, brain tumours or other neurological deficits. Visual field testing can be performed clinically by keeping the subject's gaze fixed while presenting objects at various places within their visual field. This is checked by examiner ‘s visual field considering examiner has normal fields.

questions.text:
A 3 month old child has developed persistent dyspnoea and stridor since birth. On CT scan of neck, the subglottic diameter has been found to be 2.5 mm. Subsequently, the child has been operated and a silicon tube has been placed in the airway.

What is the name of this tube?
questions.solution:
This is a case of congenital subglottic stenosis.


Montgomery's silicone tracheal T tube is used for laryngotracheal reconstruction surgery. This tube is used to support the reconstructed segment for 6 weeks.



Chevalier Jackson is another metallic tra- cheostomy tube. It has an outer and inner tube, inner is longer.

Fuller's tracheostomy tube, another type of metallic tracheostomy tube, has one advantage that because of fenestration of inner tube and biflanged outer tube, there is possibility of patient speaking with tra- cheostomy tube in situ.

Blom singer prosthesis, Panje and Provox prosthesis are examples of tracheoesophageal puncture device. It is a one way valve surgically placed between trachea and esophagus. It is used for vocal reha- bilitation after laryngectomy. It sends air from trachea to esophagus which is used to produce voice. But it does not let the food particles to go from esophagus to trachea so aspiration is not significant

choices.text: Ectopia lentis et pupillae is AD condition
Familial ectopia is superotemporal subluxation BL
In sulfite oxidase deficiency subluxation is a universal feature

questions.text: A patient came with decreased vision since many days. There is no redness or pain. On examination the slit lamp picture is as shown. What is not true about this patient
questions.solution:
• Famcrisilial is AD, bL SuperTemporal
  • Ectopia lentis et pupillae - AR pupil and lens in opposite direction

questions.text: Fibres last to be involved in glaucoma
questions.solution: Superior and inferior arcuate fibres are 1st to be involved in open angle glaucoma. They are more susceptible to damaged to high IOP. Then the papillomacular bundle (PMB). The last field to be lost in glaucoma. So nasal fibres are last go and get involved

questions.text: Kaye dot are seen in
questions.solution: Kaye dot : Kaye dots are white punctate epithelial opacities located in the epithelium anterior to the suture line of a corneal graft. The dots represent epithelial cells in various stages of degeneration on histopathology and it has been hypothesized that they may result from an epithelial response to the area of tissue angulation. Kaye dots are not visually significant and do not bear any clinical significance.

questions.text: Target sign on filter paper is a feature of
questions.solution:
Most common site of traumatic csf leak from nose is Fovea ethmoidalis. It is seen in skull base fractures e.g. Nasoethmoid Fracture, Le Fort II, III fractures. (not a feature of zygomatic and Le Fort I frac- tures)


  1. Le Fort typeI
    • horizontal maxillary fracture, separating the teeth from the upper face
    • fracture line passes through the alveolar ridge, lateral nose and inferior wall of the maxillary sinus
  2. Le Fort typeII
    • pyramidal fracture, with the teeth at the pyramid base, and nasofrontal suture at its apex
    • fracture arch passes through the posterior alveolar ridge, lateral walls of maxillary sinuses, inferior orbital rim and nasal bones
    • uppermost fracture line can pass through the nasofrontal junction or the frontal process of the maxilla
  3. Le Fort typeIII
    • craniofacial disjunction
    • trAnsverse fracture line passes through nasofrontal suture, maxillo- frontalsuture,orbital wall, and zygomatic arch / zygomaticofrontal suture
    • because of the involvement of the zygomatic arch, there is a risk of the temporalis muscle impingement

A memory aid is:

  1. LeFort I is a floating palate (horizontal)
  2. LeFort II is a floating maxilla (pyramidal)
  3. LeFort III is a floating face (trAnsverse)

choices.text: Lipophilicty increase the absorption of the topical drop
Ointment should be applied before the drops
Prior administration of anaesthetic increase the absorption of drops

questions.text: What is not correct about the eye drops
questions.solution:
As ointment is viscous so sticks to the eye and it will prevent eyedrops to get absorbed. Also eye ointment are lesser absorbed in systemic circulation

An eyedrop's absorption is increased when it is placed in conjunctival sac after administration of anesthetic drops. Also when liophillicty of eyedrop is high. A patient should ideally close the eye after putting eyed drops for approximately 5 mins.

Nasolacrimal duct occlusion by punctal occlusion also helps in increasing absorption of drops in the eye. It reduces chance of drug going into systemic circulation

questions.text: Bowed down vocalcords are seen in paralysis of which of the following nerves?
questions.solution:
Cricothyroid is main tensor of vocal cord which is supplied by external branch of SLN. Paralysis of this muscle leads to bow-ing down of vocal cords and hence loss of pitch of voice. In unilateral palsy, anteri- or commissure is rotated towards normal side which is called Askewed Glottis.

The sensory supply of larynx till vocal cords is by internal branch of superior la-ryngeal nerve. The loss of this supply can lead to aspiration. These symptoms are more pronounced in bilateral nerve dam- age.

Below the vocal cords, the sensory sup-ply is by recurrent laryngeal nerve. Vocal cords are supplied by both these nerves.

questions.text: what is false about ICRS
questions.solution:
• Intracorneal rings segments
  • Made of PMMA
  • Reversible process, redistribution of corneal stress due to change in corneal curvature.
  • Decrease corneal sensation a complication.
  • Also perforation can occcur

INTRACORNEAL RING SEGMENTS

questions.text: What type of tympanogram is given in the picture?
What is the name of this middle ear prosthesis?

Blood stained foul smelling chronic ear discahrge with otoscopy findings given in the image

What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Cholesteatoma is presence of skin in middle ear cleft. It is pearly white in clour. It has 4 types of origins.

Most common origin is Primary acquired cholesteatoma which is due to retraction pocket ( as shown in the image). Retraction pockets are more common in Pars Flaccida.

Secondary acquired Cholesteatoma are due to marginal perforation.

Tertiary acquired is due to implantation of skin in middle ear during surgery or acci- dental trauma

Congenital cholesteatoma is since birth. It presents with pearly white mass behind intact TM.

choices.text: Activity of RPE and outer segment of photoreceptors
Any lesion proximal to photoreceptor has normal EOG
A low EOG is seen in best disease

questions.text: False statement about EOG is
questions.solution:
1. ELECTROOCULOGRAM measures the resting potential of eye induced by illumination when eyes are moving side to side. It indicates activity of pigment epithelium and outer segment of rod and cones.
  2. Hence, any lesion proximal to rods and cones have a normal EOG. BEST disease shows abnormally low EOG
  3. ARDEN INDEX : Ratio of light peak over dark trough in EOG
    1. 185 : NORMAL
  4. 150-185 : BORDERLINE
  5. <150: ABNORMAL

choices.text: Total Maxillectomy in carcinoma of maxillary sinus
Partial Maxillectomy in carcinoma of maxillary sinus
Prognostic evaluation of carcinoma of maxillary sinus
Total laryngectomy in carcinoma of larynx

questions.text: What is the significance of given line in the image?
questions.solution:
Ohngren's line is from medial canthus of the eye to the angle of mandible. This line divides maxilla into superstructure and infrastructure. The malignancy of super- structure has poor prognosis due to prox- imity to orbit.

Weber fergusson incision is used for total maxillectomy


Moure's incision is used for lateral rhi- notomy for medial maxillectomy which is done in inverted papilloma


Gluck Sorenson incision is used for total laryngectomy

questions.text: A 55 year old male patient presented with ptosis and restricted eye upward movement which have worsened for last few months. His horizontal gazes are otherwise normal. No diplopia is complained off. Pupils are also normal. Posterior segment examination is also unremarkable. What is your diagnosis
questions.solution:
Chronic progressive external ophthalmoplegia

  • BL ptosis
  • No pupillary involvement
  • 1st upgaze later lateral also gone
  • EMG done for diagnosis
  • Serum Creatine kinase also increases

questions.text: Identify the investigation being done in the given picture.
SMILE is a
questions.solution:
• in LASIK the flap creation is done either with a microkeratome of femtolaser
  • But in SMILE (small incisional lenticular extraction), no flap is created and the desired stromal thickness is taken out with the help of a lenticule created through femtolasers in the corneal stroma. So no flap is needed. Also the incision through which the lenticule is removed is made by the same laser.
  • Hence there is no chance of flap related complications in SMILE.
  • Also it gives precision to the refractive surgery

questions.text: Identify the circular part of cochlear implant placed on the side of scalp (given in the picture)
Subjective verification of refraction is done by
questions.solution:
• A subjective refraction where the result depends on the patient's ability to discern changes in clarity. This process relies on the cooperation of the patient.
  • An objective refraction (usually retinoscopy) where the result depends purely on the examiner's judgement to determine the optimum optical correct
  • Jackson Cross Cylinder: a combination of two cylinders whose powers are numerically equal and of opposite sign (+/-) and whose axis are perpendicular to one another. This is used to search for astigmatism.
  • DuochromeTest: used to check the spherical component of the refraction
  • Astigmatic fan You can test whether you have any astigmatism by looking at the diagram of the fan chart.

choices.text: Follicular conjunctivitis can be a presenting feature in almost 3 to 5% of patients
Vascular occlusions can also be seen
Conjunctivitis is mostly within the second or third week of covid
Conjunctival fornix secretions may be positive for corona virus

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Covid 19 manifestation in eye
questions.solution: Follicular conjunctivitis can be a presenting feature in almost 3 to 5% of patients. Conjunctivitis is mostly within the end of 1st week of covid. Conjunctivitis here is self limiting usually. Vascular occlusions can also be seen and they are the most common cause of loss of vision in covid 19. Conjunctival fornix secretions may be positive for corona virus and hence the spread is seen by this method as well. The most common adnexal /orbital involvement in COVID is Dacryoadenitis . Toclizumab used in COVID 19 can cause Cotton wool spots, Retinal hemorrhage and Microaneurysm in retina

questions.text: Which of the following airway obstruction level causes inspiratory stridor?
questions.solution: The stridor meAns noisy breathing. It is due to airway obstruction. Depending on the level of obstruction, it is of three types.

questions.text: A 6 year old Child operated for Adeno- tonsillectomy has developed atlantoaxial subluxation. What is the possible diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Grisel's syndrome, defined as subluxation of the atlantoaxial joint, not associated with trauma or bone disease, is found primarily in children. This syndrome has been observed after otolaryngologic procedures such as adenoidectomy. It presents with torticollis, neck stiffness. X-rays and computed tomography scAns of the cervical spine can confirm the diagnosis. Early management, consisting of cervical immobilization and medical treatment, is considered the key factor for a satisfactory outcome.

Neurological complications have been reported in the literature, ranging from mild paresthesia, clonus, to quadriplegia or acute respiratory failure and death so neurosurgical consultation is required.

This complication is more common in Down's syndrome children.

Kallmann's syndrome Anomia with hypogonadism Eagle syndrome = styalgia

Long styloid process pressing glossopharyngeal nerve presenting with throat pain radiating to ear.

Ortner syndrome

Left atriomegaly casing left recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy

choices.text: Urgent MRI to be done to check mass in brain
Ischemic CRVO should be ruled out

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man came to your OPD with mild blurred vision after the recent diagnosis of severe hypertension since 2 days. Otherwise, his medical and family histories were unremarkable. He used to smoke more than 5 cigarettes per days. On admission, his blood pressure was 240/140 mmHg. His anterior segment is normal but retina shows this picture.

What is true about his condition
questions.solution:
This patient has a malignant hypertension with a very high BP levels. According to Keith and Wagner classification fourth grade of hypertensive retinopathy shows Bl papilledema

It is a clinical diagnosis mainly.

Keith-Wagner- Barker classification

  • Group 1: Slight constriction of retinal arterioles
  • Group 2: Group 1 + focal narrowing of retinal arterioles + AV nicking
  • Group 3: Group 2 + flame-shaped haemorrhages + cotton-wool spots + hard exudates
  • Group 4: Group 3 + optic disc swelling/ papilledema

Scheie Classification

For Hypertensive Retinopathy

  • Stage 1: Diffuse arteriolar narrowing
  • Stage 2: Stage 1 + focal arteriolar constriction
  • Stage 3: Stage 2 + retinal hemorrhage
  • Stage 4: Stage 3 + hard exudates + retinal edema+ optic disc swelling

For Arteriosclerosis

  • Stage 1: Broadening of arteriolar light reflex
  • Stage 2: Stage 1 + AV crossing changes
  • Stage 3: Copper wiring of arterioles
  • Stage 4: Silver wiring of arterioles

choices.text: Most common cause of epiphora in infancy
Bluish swelling above the medial canthus
Amniotic fluid in lacrimal sac due to imperforate hasner's valve
Syringing and probing are the treatment of choice, done as early as possible

questions.text: True about dacryoceole
questions.solution:
• Dacryocele is also known as a dacryocystocele. It is formed when a distal blockage of the lacrimal sac causes distention of the sac that also kinks and closes off the entrance to the common canaliculus.
  • Patients present with a bluish swelling just below and nasal to the medial canthus.
  • Dacryocele may respond to conservative management with prophylactic topical antibiotics and digital massage.
  • Definitive treatment consists of eliminating the NLDO by probing, which can be undertaken once the initial inflammation has resolved

questions.text: A congenitally deaf child with bilateral profound SNHL on radiological evaluation has been found to have intact eighth nerve on both sides. What is the best method of hearing rehabilitation in this case.
questions.solution:
Cochlear Implant is a device that converts sound to electrical energy and directly stimulates cochlear nerve fibres electrically (8th nerve). Hence, integrity of 8th nerve is vital for this surgery Indication

Bilateral profound or severe to profound hearing loss with no benefit seen with hearing aid

Parts of cochlear implant:

  1. External parts Microphone Speech processor Transmitter Battery
  2. Internal parts Reciever stimulator (electrode) Surgical technique
  3. The classical approach is posterior tympanotomy (facial recess approach)
  4. Other surgical technique is Veria approach This is transcanal approach Insertionof electrode through Cochleostomy/or through round window membrane Where the electrodes are placed?

Scala tympani Types of implant:

Single channel (house- 3M device) Multiple channel (nucleus device)- 22 channel-much better

Speech therapy is must after cochlear im- plantation

Mondini dysplasia of cochlea refers to the condition when there are one and half turns of cochlea rather than two and half. There is absence of the apical modiolus and interscalar septum, resulting in an incomplete partitioning of the cochlea together with an enlarged vestibular aqueduct (EVA) and dilated vestibule. This is not a contraindication of cochlear implantation.

choices.text: 24 hour double probe pH monitoring

questions.text: Gold standard test for laryngopharyngeal reflux is?
questions.solution: Laryngopharyngeal reflux is best diagnosed with 24 hour double probe pH monitoring.

questions.text: A 14 year old boy has presenting with recurrent episodes of profuse epistaxis and reddish nasal mass is seen filling nasal cavity. What is the possible diagnosis
questions.solution:
This is a case of Angiofibroma. Angiofibro- ma is the most common benign tumour of nasopharynx seen in adolescent males. It originates from sphenopalatine foramen. It's a highly vascular tumour.

CECT scan shows Hollman Miller (=An- tral) sign. Surgery is treatment of choice. Pre-op embolisation will reduce blood loss. Pre-op Estrogen, Flutamide (andro- gen antagonist) are helpful in reducing blood loss. Biopsy of this tumour is never done as it is a highly vascular tumour.

Radkowski staging and Fisch staging of Angiofibroma

questions.text: A 20 year male came to you with complaint of discomfort by his glasses and frequent change in number You observe a sign in him when he is asked to look down which is shown in the picture. All are other signs can be expected in him except
questions.solution:
This is a sign seen in thyroid ophthalmopathy. Joffroy's sign is a clinical sign in which there is a lack of wrinkling of the forehead when a patient looks up with the head bent forwards.

In this given picture there is Munson sign which means notching of lower lid on looking down.

Scissoring reflex on retinoscopy, Oil droplet reflex on ophthalmoscopy are seen in keratoconus.

This disorder Rizzutti sign is Sharply focused conical beam of light near the nasal limbus, produced by lateral illumination of the cornea from temporal side, in patients with advanced keratoconus

questions.text: Onodi cells and Haller cells of ethmoid are related respectively to:
questions.solution:
These are variations of ethmoidal air cells. Haller cell is a variation of anterior ethmoid air cells and they lie in relation to orbital floor.

Onodi cell is a variation of posterior ethmoid and lie in relation to optic nerve. When present they can increase the chance of complications during FESS. Another variation of ethmoid air cells is Concha bullosa which meAns pneuma- tised middle turbinate.

Few points about normal ethmoid air cells

  1. Anterior ethmoid air cells are from2-8. Posterior ethmoid air cells are 1-8
  2. Anteriorand posterior ethmoid cells are separated by basal lamella =ground lamella
  3. Aggernasi is the anterior most anterior ethmoidal air cell.
  4. Bulla ethmoidalis is the most constant and largest anterior ethmoid air cell

questions.text: A 35 year old man came with redness, pain and photophobia in one eye since few days. On examination the pupil was small, but reacting to light. Circumcorneal congestion was also noted. There is a non productive cough also. He also told about tender nodules on his shin. Chest X ray showed B/L hilar lymphadenopathy. What is your diagnosis
questions.solution:
• Sarcoidosis is a very close differential diagnosis
  • Non caseating granuloma, Hilar lymphadenopathy and Erythema nodosum are the presenting features here
  • Circumcorneal congestion, small pupil are suggestive of uveitis which is associated with sarcoidosis.
  • Meiosis is due to spasm of sphincter pupillae muscle in inflammation

questions.text: Which of the following describes Type III cordectomy correctly?
questions.solution: To understand types of cordectomy, we need to see the histological picture of true vocal cord (see image)

questions.text: The progression of ocular hypertension to POAG is determined by all except
questions.solution:
• Risk factor for POAG - as per ocular hypertension study.
  • Advancing age, black races, male, myopia, increased vertical cup to disc ratio, decreased corneal thickness, and a positive family history.

questions.text: What is the best treatment of reactionary hemorrhage after tonsillectomy?
questions.solution:
(i). Reactionary hemorrhage is seenwithin 24 hours of It is due to slip- page of ligature and it should be immediately re-explored under GA.

(ii). Secondary hemorrhage is seen after 5th day of tonsillectomy. It is due to infection of tonsillar fossa and is managed with I/V antibiotics.

questions.text: A 56 year old man has complaints of frequent change of presbyopic glasses with heaviness in his eye. On examination his vision is 6/6, angles are open with an IOP of 18 mmHg on goldman applanation tonometer. His mother had open angle glaucoma. His CCT is 440 microns. Retina check up reveals a CDR of 0.8 : 1. His visual fields are normal. What is next step you will plan.
questions.solution:
This patient has a low CCT so his corrected IOP is 23 mmHg which is higher than the normal. His CDR is 0.8 : 1 also his complaints are also suggestive of POAG.

So ideally patient should be started on antiglaucoma drugs.

questions.text: Which of the following can not be seen on indirect laryngoscopy

choices.text: A short course of steroids under antibiotic cover are given
Cysticercosis should be ruled out by USG

questions.text: A 34 year old man presents with painful proptosis with diplopia. He described the eye are also red since few days. CT scan shows a diffuse thickening of muscles and tendinous insertions. What would you further do
questions.solution:
• The disorder in this question suggest a pseudo tumour.
  • IOI or orbital pseudotumor is the second most common cause of exophthalmos following Grave's orbitopathy. It can range from a diffuse inflammatory process to a more localized inflammation of muscle, lacrimal gland or orbital fat. It presents with sudden painful proptosis, redness, and edema. Occasionally, ptosis, chemosis, motility dysfunction, and optic neuropathy are seen. There is diffuse involvement of the muscle along with its tendon. Many respond to corticosteroid treatment alone, there are several cases in which adjuvant therapy like cytotoxic drugs, immunosuppresents, biological agents are given. In thyroid, Muscle tendon remains unaffected.

questions.text: Which is the correct site of implantation of brain stem implantation
questions.solution:
Brain stem implant is placed on lateral recess of 4th ventricle near cochlear nucleus for stimulation.

The indications are NF-2 cases with bi- lateral acoustic neuromas, congenital absence of VIII nerve, cochlear aplasia(Michel's)

questions.text: Trotter's triad has all features except
questions.solution: Trotter's triad is a feature of Nasopharyngeal carcinoma. It has temporoparietal pain (due to 5th nerve involvement), palatal palsy (due to 10th nerve involvement) and unilateral conductive hearing loss (due to serous otitis media).

choices.text: Sensory end organ of Utricle and saccule
Sensory end organ of semicircular canals

questions.text: What is Cupula in inner ear?
questions.solution:
Crista is the sensory end organ of semi- circular canals. It lies in Ampulla of canals which is a dilated end of SCC. Crista is surrounded by gelatinous layer called Cu- pula.

Otoliths or otoconia are calcium carbonate crystals lying embedded in the gelatinous layer of macula. Macula is the sensory end organ of utricle and saccule whose function is linear acceleration.

questions.text: Fluoroscein dye disappearance test is for
questions.solution:
• A fluorescein dye disappearance test is used in children and adults to find out whether tear are draining normally from the eye into the nose.
  • One drop of a special dye (fluorescein) or a paper strip containing the dye is placed between the eyelid and the eye
  • After 10 to 15 minutes, the doctor looks in your eye using a blue light. The light can detect very small amounts of fluorescent dye. The doctor may also use the light to look in your throat and inside your nose.
  • Normally, tears sweep the dye out of the eye and into the tear ducts. If dye stays in the eye, the tear duct may be blocked.

choices.text: A Vertical bony septum in Internal Auditory

questions.text: What is Bill's bar?
questions.solution:
Bill's bar is a landmark that divides the superior compartment of the internal acoustic meatus =canal into an anterior and posterior compartment.

Anterior to Bill bar, in the anterior superior quadrant, is the facial nerve (CN VII) and posterior to it in the posterior superior quadrant is the superior division of the vestibular nerve

questions.text:
Oropharyngeal picture of a patient with Trismus, plummy voice and dysphagia is shown in the given image.

What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of quinsy=peritonsillar abscess. Tonsil is pushed medillay and uvula is deviated to other side. This is classical feature of quinsy. There is NO outer neck swelling in Quinsy. Patient has Trismus (due to spasm of medial pterygoid muscle), odynophagia, hot potato voice.



If similar history and examination findings are there along with neck swelling close to angle of mandible, then the diagnosis is parapharyngeal abscess.

Acute retropharyngeal abscess - Commonly seen in children < 3yrs

  • Results of suppuration of retropharyngealLN
  • In adults - from penetrating injury of post. pharyngealwall
  • C/F :
    • Dysphagia & difficulty in breath- ing (prominent symp)
    • Stridor
    • Bulge in post. Pharyngeal wall (usually seen on one side of midline)

Xray STN lat. view - widening of prevertebral shadow

T/t - airway management, I & D without GA, antibiotics

Quiencke's disease is sudden idiopathic isolated angioedema of uvula. It is due to food allergy or idiopathic. Intravenous steroids are given to manage it

questions.text: A 14 year old boy came to the OPD with complaints of decrease in vision in right eye. N examination his vision is 6/12. On examination a yellow lesion was seen in macula. There was a similar history of decrease in vision in his father in his childhood. What is most important for the diagnosis.
questions.solution:
This patient has AD, best disease (family history present) father also has similar history.

  • ELECTROOCULOGRAM measures the resting potential of eye induced by illumination when eyes are moving side to side. It indicates activity of pigment epithelium and outer segment of rod and cones.
  • Hence, any lesion proximal to rods and cones have a normal EOG. BEST disease shows abnormally low EOG
  • ARDEN INDEX : Ratio of light peak over dark trough in EOG
    • 185 : NORMAL
  • 150-185 : BORDERLINE
  • <150: ABNORMAL

questions.text:
A 29 year old HIV positive individual presents to emergency in a critical state with deranged vitals. The examination shows a blackish necrotic debris in the nasal cavity with necrosed skin of external nose.

What is the best treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
Mucormycosis (rhinocerebral phycomycosis):

  1. Isan aggressive opportunistic fungal infection
  2. Organism: Order: Mucor/Rhizopusory- zae
  3. Predisposing factors: immunosup- pressed patients (HIV), uncontrolled youngdiabetics

Features:

  1. Remarkable affinity for blood vessels-arteries
  2. Leads to extensive endothelial damage & thrombosis

Findings:

The disease begins in the nose, invade → P.N.S → orbit →cribiform plate→ menin- ges → brain

Typical Finding

  1. Black necrotic mass seen filling theen- tire nasal cavity
  2. Erosion of the nasal septrum and the hard palate may beappreciable

There is anesthesia over face, nose with reduced mucosal bleeding

M.R.I. Detects early vascular and intrac- ranial invasion

Treatment:

  • Systemic amphotericin (Liposomal)
  • Local debridement

questions.text: Inverse glaucoma is seen in
questions.solution:
• INVERSE GLAUCOMA
    • Secondary glaucoma is either due to anterior dislocation of lens Or it may be due to narrowing of the angle of anterior chamber due to hyperplasia of ciliary body and sphero-phakia. seen in Weil Marchesani's Syndrome
    • Inverse glaucoma is also called as pupillary block glaucoma where rise in tension is aggravated by miotics.
